story: Mahmoud Tantawy shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: How and why the leap second affected Cloudflare DNS
caption: blog.cloudflare.com
description: At midnight UTC on New Year’s Day, deep inside Cloudflare’s custom RRDNS software, a number went negative when it should always have been, at worst, zero. A little later this negative value caused RRDNS to panic. This panic was caught using the recover feature of the Go language.

data.message:
Can someone explain to me where the "negative" time difference exactly comes from? i.e. what happens to "time.now()" during the leap second.

The way I understand it, so far, is that clocks are just "slowed down". So let's say time.now() returns 23:59:59.0, then 23:59:59.1 and so on until 23:59:59.9 and then 00:00:00 it will take 2 "real-life seconds", but it has still been perceived by the program as 1 normal, forward-moving second.

What did I miss? Am I even making sense :) ?

It is a subtle detail, but a programmer should be careful when using real and monotonic times. Real times should be used when displaying dates. Monotonic times should be used when calculating elapsed time. The first time a leap second was added to the Linux kernel (2012), it caused a huge mess. But it was handled smoothly the second time it was added (2015).
